title: How AI Helped an Eyewear Brand Reduce Rx Verification Time by 95%, Cutting Costs & Growing Revenue

rawLines.text: Today we're speaking with Nitesh Punt,
co-founder of Dev Dash Labs, who helps
SMB founders overcome operational
bottlenecks with custom AI solutions.
Nesh, welcome to Just Curious.
Happy to be here, Stu.
Tell me a little bit about yourself. Who
is Nitesh? What led you to start
focusing on helping SMBs and startups
use AI to solve problems?
I'm Nitesh. I'm co-founder of Dave Dash
Labs. um were an AI research and
development company. Our story starts
around mid 2024. I found myself building

Uh I think that's crap. So I said you

said I'm going to make an impact here.
So we started focusing almost

and we started giving them you know
researchbacked custom AI solutions with

Awesome. And we're going to walk through

founders and leaders effectively
identify which bottlenecks or problems

Uh that's a great question. So a couple

first would be tasks that are taking 10
15 it would have been 20 hours per week
um for a founder and if those tasks are

very repeatable and have a certain
process around it those are the first
what we call easy wins of AI
implementation that's part one and I
guess the second part is what we call
scaling unique value. So a lot of our
clients are professional services
companies that have been domain experts
for the past 5 10 years. They have built
processes they have built IP knowledge
bases around it and when you're at that
point you can't just talk to chat GBT
and expect it to understand the world in
your viewpoint. you have to build out
agents that you know can ingest your uh
client's data and process it and work
work with it from your viewpoint. So I
guess those are two major themes righted
process and stuff where you know your IP
can be the moat.
Interesting. Is there um is there a
process to identify the the first
bottleneck? Uh do you interview everyone
on the team? Do you look at your
calendar? enourage you just make a note
of where you're spending your time and
then you know when it feels like you're
spending a lot of time doing a
replicable process um that sort of
that's it how do you usually go about
identifying those opportunities
so we personally we we run workshops AI
discovery workshops that do it for you
but there's different ways to do it
right so first is as you said really
understanding where is it that you
you're as a founder you're facing this
bottlenecks where is is it that you're
doing replicable processes or is it that
you know you could use automation? Um I
like to think of it as an intern test.
If you can you know teach an intern
about two three hours of work and
hopefully over the course of a week they
get better at it. Um that's probably
something you could spin an AI agent to
do u a custom AI agent to do for you. So
um that's one way to look about it. uh
other way is to you know always start
with the problem right uh instead of the
you know what am I doing it's what are
the problems that I'm solving and can I
now you solve these problems using AI
can we also expand on
the um the second opportunity you
suggested which is to leverage your um
IP in new and different ways using

maybe give us a short kind of example

services firm.

that to build on these models, you need

equation.
You need your IP, right? And you need a

project. And um your talent pipeline
that's there like you know your actual
consultants. Client data is client data.
For AI, it has to be a little bit more

building or training as we call it

Got it. So these are internal tools that

Exactly. Yes. So what we've found is

percent. Why not?

Work start from the problem, not not the

walk, day in the life of a CEO or
right
in the life of a CEO type exercise and

thinking, okay, what are good

the pain point right it's a symptom of

many times it might not even involve

it's really solving those problems. And
if there's a case that there is tech

Yeah.
Yeah. I want to um I want to dig a

You ask why is a lot. So like X is like

Yeah. Let's walk through the case study

a lot of marketing effort that was

for the highest value to impact would

yeah so um the client was a eyewear

um now not every prescription

How did you go about designing a

So we you know when you're designing a

taking the entire almost most of was a

what what we designed was a system where

It now goes to our AWS servers, right?
You're collecting the data. You're

there's different like like there's

it's not in our confidence range that we

cool and so the the before state was

for the most part like fully automated

but a much faster process and one that

you're waiting a couple days someone may

They were great. They were great. So,

10 hours of contractor per week was

and so that increased conversion
um I think it was something like

that over the year they'll have over

Yeah. So you both cut costs, which I

the
Yeah.
Yeah.
And how long did it take to deploy this?
About four to six weeks. Um, so took

Yeah. Yeah. What other types of

Yes. Right. First, you know, one thing

Maybe other professional services, I

What a great example. Many SMBs and

for someone considering

I think we talked about this. It's

That is without doubt the first step

Try to build custom workflows using

Give your team permission to experiment

um automation solutions that you'll see

Yeah.
So, yeah.
Cool. Um, as we like look forward, what

That's a great question. A couple of

I love it. Um, Nutach, thank you so much

cleanText:
Today we're speaking with Nitesh Pant, co-founder of DevDash Labs, who helps SMB founders overcome operational bottlenecks with custom AI solutions. Nitesh, welcome to Just Curious.

Happy to be here, Stu.

Tell me a little bit about yourself. Who is Nitesh? What led you to start focusing on helping SMBs and startups use AI to solve problems?

I'm Nitesh. I'm co-founder of DevDash Labs. We're an AI research and development company. Our story starts around mid-2024. I found myself building opportunities, and this gave me time to dive deep into what was happening in AI, especially around the emerging agent intake space that most people weren't talking about back then, and I started building and releasing a few products. And what I saw was a massive gap on what I was doing and what LinkedIn was doing, or you know, what LinkedIn experts were doing, right? So then till now, it's full of people who probably haven't written a single line of code but are selling promises, impossible promises, to business owners who want real solutions. I think that's crap. So I said, you know, I have had enough of that, and I said I'm going to make an impact here. So we started focusing almost exclusively on SMBs and startups, and we started giving them, you know, research-backed custom AI solutions with measurable ROI instead of just empty promises. And then it came down to seeing a problem and getting fed up with the status quo and deciding to do something about it.

Awesome. And we're going to walk through an example of one of your engagements in a few minutes. Maybe we could start with bottlenecks and problems. How can founders and leaders effectively identify which bottlenecks or problems are best suited to AI automation?

Uh, that's a great question. So a couple of themes stand out. First would be tasks that are taking 10, 15, it would have been 20 hours per week for a founder, and if those tasks are repeated and they have a certain process around it, right? So long tasks, very repeatable, and have a certain process around it, those are the first, what we call, easy wins of AI implementation. That's part one. And I guess the second part is what we call scaling unique value. So a lot of our clients are professional services companies that have been domain experts for the past 5, 10 years. They have built processes, they have built intellectual property knowledge bases around it, and when you're at that point, you can't just talk to chat GPT and expect it to understand the world in your viewpoint. You have to build out agents that you know, can ingest your client's data and process it and work with it from your viewpoint. So I guess those are two major themes, right? Process and stuff where, you know, your IP can be the moat.

Interesting. Is there a process to identify the first bottleneck? Do you interview everyone on the team? Do you look at your calendar? Encourage you just make a note of where you're spending your time, and then you know, when it feels like you're spending a lot of time doing a replicable process, um, that sort of, that's it. How do you usually go about identifying those opportunities?

So we personally, we run workshops, AI discovery workshops that do it for you, but there's different ways to do it, right? So first is, as you said, really understanding where is it that you, you're as a founder, you're facing this bottlenecks, where is it that you're doing replicable processes, or is it that, you know, you could use automation? I like to think of it as an intern test. If you can, you know, teach an intern about two, three hours of work, and hopefully over the course of a week they get better at it, that's probably something you could spin an AI agent to do, a custom AI agent to do for you. So, um, that's one way to look about it. Uh, other way is to, you know, always start with the problem, right? Uh, instead of the, you know, what am I doing, it's what are the problems that I'm solving, and can I now you solve these problems using AI?

Can we also expand on the um, the second opportunity you suggested, which is to leverage your um, IP in new and different ways using agents? What does that look like in practice? And maybe give us, I know we're going to walk through a case study, but maybe give us a short kind of example, like, and we can blind it of like what that would look like for a professional services firm.

So, you know, if and by professional services, it's um, often consulting companies, boutique companies. And you know, between consulting companies, they have frameworks that they've built out, they have processes, workflows, models, right? And one thing that's constant is that to build on these models, you need client data. That's one part of the equation. You need your IP, right? And you need a brain to process that. So your IP comes down from past projects you've worked on, some institutional knowledge you've um, developed in the while doing this project.
